summary: W. David Slawson was a staff member of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy, also known as the Warren Commission. He engaged in discussions with the CIA regarding inconsistencies between information provided by the CIA and the Department of State concerning the OSWALDs' departure from the USSR. The CIA's support to the Warren Commission in 1964 included work related to Lee Harvey Oswald's activities in the USSR. A New York Times article reported that the Warren Commission was not fully informed about the CIA's secret taping of telephone conversations between Lee Harvey Oswald and the Cuban and Soviet Embassies in Mexico City weeks before President Kennedy's assassination due to concerns over exposing CIA sources and methods.
significance: W. David Slawson's significance lies in his role as a staff member of the Warren Commission, where he was involved in investigating the assassination of President Kennedy. His discussions with the CIA regarding inconsistencies in information related to Lee Harvey Oswald's activities highlight the complexities and potential discrepancies in the information provided to the Commission.
